Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Central Florida Media Convergence Laboratory, New York Hall of Science, and the Queens Museum of Art are developing a 3-D, multi-user virtual environment (MUVE) of the 1964/65 New York World's Fair. Virtual fairgoers of all ages will be immersed in an accurately modeled historical world with more than 140 pavilions on science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines and an array arts and humanities exhibits. The virtual world can be freely explored through self-designed avatars, and avatar-led guided tours. Discovery Points throughout the virtual environment will afford opportunities for in-depth engagement in STEM topics that will empower participants to explore the broader consequences of technological innovations.

The centerpiece of user-generated content is FutureFair, an area where online users can create and share their personal visions of the future. Interconnections reaches beyond its virtual component through its partnership with the New York Hall of Science and the Queens Museum of Art, which are both situated in the heart of Queens in Flushing Meadows Corona Park, a 1255 acre urban park that hosted the 1939/1940 and 1964/65 Fairs. The New York Hall of Science will provide face-to-face youth workshops that employ problem-based learning. Single and multi-session programs will connect adolescents to STEM content presented at the Fair through the virtual world environment. Participants will create multimedia content for inclusion in the project's website. Multi-touch interactive stations at the Queens Museum of Art will enhance their NY World's Fair Exhibit Hall by empowering visitors to individually or collectively explore various STEM topics and the symbiotic relationships between STEM and the humanities, and by serving as an attractor for visitors to the online Fair exploration. The project will be completed in time for the 50th Anniversary celebration of the 1964 World's Fair.

Building upon prior research on learning in virtual worlds, the project team will investigate how STEM concepts are advanced in a simulated multi-user virtual environment and studying the effectiveness of using Virtual Docents as enhancements to the informal learning process. The research and development deliverables have strong potential to advance the state of informal science education, research on modeling and simulation in virtual world development, and education research. Michigan Technological University will conduct the project formative and summative evaluations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Central Florida (UCF) received funding from the National Science Foundation through the Informal Science Education program (# 0840297) to create a virtual STEM learning environment for youths between the ages of 8 and 12 entitled Interconnections: Revisiting the Future. Project deliverables include a downloadable 3D virtual STEM learning  environment that utilizes the backdrop of the 1964/65 New York World’s Fair.  Interconnections--renamed ChronoLeap--reaches beyond the virtual through project partners the Queens Museum and the New York Hall of Science.  Public programs at the New York Hall of Science enriched the virtual experience through hands-on interaction with the larger topics and technologies featured at actual 1964/65 New York World’s Fair. An interactive exhibit at the Queens Museum uses the Fair as a springboard to linking culture and technology of the mid-1960s with contemporary life, and in so doing, entices users to investigate the downloadable virtual STEM experience.

Designed by UCF's  Synthetic Reality Lab, ChronoLeap utilizes the various pavilions at the Fair as vehicles through which to address basic Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) concepts; demonstrates the evolution of science and technology from the time of the Fair to the present; and examines why some of the visions of the future presented at the Fair were achieved, others were exceeded, and others never reached. The project also examines the effectiveness of STEM transfer through intergenerational interaction in virtual environments, demonstrating that such a paired approach increases knowledge transfer from elders to youth and vice versa, as well as improving user interest and information retention.

In addition to its contributions to STEM education, ChronoLeap incorporates basic research in computer science and more specifically in serious game design and human-computer interaction. The serious games contributions include the real-time capture and delivery of a game with realistic, complex graphical models and content within the context of an experience that keeps the attention of youth (high quality graphics and motivating game mechanics) while providing a meaningful learning experience. The human-computer interaction contributions provide engaging and natural interaction paradigms for computer-based games and whole body interaction at museums.

Formative and summative evaluations were conducted by Dr. Karla Saari Kitalong, Professor of Humanities at Michigan Technological University. The four-year formative evaluation cycle began with proof-of-concept testing and ended with final prototype testing. Formative evaluation results strongly suggested that the environment be modified from the original exploratory “sandbox” into a goal-oriented, leveled game undergirded by clear player learning objectives. The leveled game concept addressed both usability concerns and technology issues related to the size and complexity of the download.

Interconnections was recast as a multi-level game-like environment and renamed ChronoLeap! The Great World’s Fair Adventure.
